The abatement of nitrogen oxides coming to the atmosphere from diesel engines of automotive vehicles and marine vessels, industrial plants, and other sources is of profound importance. Currently, catalysis-based solutions show growing potential in addressing this challenge. The main requirements that SCR catalysts should meet include enhanced low-temperature activity and selectivity combined with a broad operating window, high resistance to poisons and moisture. While a plethora of SCR catalysts has been proposed by now, recently, a growing number of publications have emphasized the unlocked potential of bimetallic catalyst formulations. Among them, Ag-based systems deserve special attention due to their high performance and relative cheapness. The present review is focused on the recent achievements recorded in the latest 5–10 years on bimetallic Ag-based catalysts for low-temperature SCR. Systems, such as Ag-Pt, Ag-Au, Ag-Cu, Ag-Fe, Ag-Mn, are considered and compared with bi-and polymetallic transition metals. The role of catalysts preparation method, Ag loading, metal-support interaction and pre-treatment effects has been pointed out. The outlook of the future research challenges is provided. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords NOx emissions Selective reduction Low-temperature process Silver-based catalyst Bimetallic system Data availability The present manuscript is review and includes only published results/data form original research articles. 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides (NOx) are globally considered the major pollutants of the atmosphere in industrial countries and cause harmful impacts on the environment and human health [4,45,51,73]. The NOx emissions from diesel vehicle engines operating under various external conditions also constitute an important challenge [30] due to the strict governmental regulations and ESG (Environment, Social, Governance) trends. Currently, the main methods used to remove NOx are connected with selective catalytic reduction (SCR), selective noncatalytic high-temperature reduction, nonselective catalytic reduction as well as sorption-based approaches. While the 100% efficiency of modern practically used technologies for low-temperature NOx removal is still not achieved, it can be ensured and controlled to a large extent by applying catalysis-based solutions, especially selective catalytic reduction (SCR). The main challenges for SCR catalysts are associated with ensuring enhanced low-temperature activity, broad operating window, and improved hydrothermal stability [169]. Additionally, it is challenging to ensure high resistances towards SO2 [182,50,94], heavy (e.g., Cd [92], Pb [60], Zn [167]) and alkali [14,16] metals. With that, the promoting effect of sulfur-containing compounds (e.g., CS2, COS) was also recently described [107,165,23] making the issue debating. Generally, the catalytic NOx purification using SCR comprises a reduction of a mixture of nitrogen oxides into molecular nitrogen and water with various reductants (e.g., urea [166], CO [136], H2 [199,201,76], hydrocarbons (HC) [130,143,180], biodiesel [132], alcohols [12,155,21] and other oxygenates (OHC) [146,68,80] as well as their mixtures [193,2,212,49,54,6]). The use of oxygenate-based approaches shows high potential in NOx removal due to the opportunities to use gas mixtures with compositions similar to those of the off-gases and lower combustion temperatures in comparison with the HC-SCR process. The use of NH3 is complicated due to the fact that during the low-temperature range of the cycle a large amount of ammonia can be desorbed at elevated temperatures over acid sites emitting with the off-gases. As a rule, to achieve the completeness of NOx reduction, the NH3 excess is used, that results in the additional stage of reductant removal. Because of the high importance of the NOx abatement, many catalyst formulations have been proposed and extensively studied. Fig. 1 clearly shows the rapidly growing number of publications in this area (Fig. 1). Recent publications discuss in detail the composites based on zeolite-supported Rh [196], Ag [7], Cu (SAPO-34 [164,174], SSZ-13 [109,113], ZSM-5 [195] chabazite [86,162], etc.)] and Fe (SAPO [43,99], SSZ [142], Beta [120], ZSM-5 [24], etc.) systems. Generally, zeolite-supported catalysts feature low-temperature activity and efficient performance at elevated space velocities accompanied by high thermal durability, while suffering from SO2 poisoning. Layered materials, namely, the catalysts derived from double hydroxides [188], oxides [198], and silicas [29], demonstrate potential due to the opportunities to ensure high dispersion of metal ions, improved thermal stability, and widened operating window. The main disadvantages are due to materials aggregation and demanding preparation procedures. Moreover, when the temperature increases, the support degradation accompanied by partial degradation of the layered structure occurs. The composites based on transition metals bring about high research interest due to the appearance of multiple oxidation states and high compatibility with traditional supports (alumina, titania, silica, etc.). The V- and W-based catalysts [183,204] feature high middle-temperature activity and sulfur poisoning resistance. However, low- and high-temperature activities are rather moderate, and increased SO2 oxidation ability is usually observed. The Mn-based systems [181] feature improved low-temperature activity and hydrothermal stability, while still suffer from SO2 effects. Rare-earth elements (La [102], Sm [97,158], Eu [147], Pr [31], Tb, Er, Yb [74], etc.) draw increasing attention, while the researchers are mainly focused on Ce-based [13,153,170,184] formulations attempting to find a balance between the redox and acid-base properties of the surfaces and incorporate positive effects of transition metal oxides. Indeed, the effects of ceria support pretreatment [52,211] and modification [114], type of precursor [42] and dispersion of ceria [137], engineering of surface defects (mainly, oxygen vacancies [200,202,210]) as well as the interfaces between redox and acid sites [58] on the catalyst morphology and catalyst performance were examined. The high performance of CeO2-based catalysts is determined by optimal surface acidity, special redox characteristics, high oxygen release and storage capacity, and resistance towards SO2 and H2O at 300–500 °C. However, at low temperatures, the resistance of ceria-based catalysts towards SO2 and H2O is required. With that, the potential of ceria modification by other metals, e.g., Y that was shown for several catalytic reactions [56,81], can be further explored. High performance of systems utilizing individual transition metal oxides led to growing interest in binary systems such as Mn-Ce [171,208,89,90] that can be also organized on various supports (e.g., Al2O3 [159,160], TiO2 [123,186,187],TNU [59], ZSM-5 [185]). The Mn-iron triad metals (Mn-Fe [104,105,209], Mn-Co [83] and Mn-Ni [176], Mn-V [172,173,191]) were also considered in an attempt to combine valuable properties of both components. The Ce-based systems also formed binary SCR composites such as Ce-Fe [108,197], Ce-V [75], Ce-In [139], Ce-Co [1], Ce-Si [152], while most attention is paid to Ce-Ti [106,118,93,98] and Ce-W [150,151,177,44,64,82] pairs, with their combined synergistic effects being closely examined [101,103,17,192,203,61]. Generally, such composites demonstrate improved balance between redox and acid properties, while several other components are usually involved making it challenging to decipher their individual roles. Noble [91] metals were also actively studied, with the materials based on Pt [20,34,72], Pd [138,22,53], Rh [129], and Ru [28] being most thoroughly investigated due to both high activity and an opportunity to induce high hydrothermal stability and moderate SO2 resistance in combination with various supports such as Al2O3, CeO2, TiO2, MgO. Moreover, such metals can affect the process mechanism to facilitate the formation of the key reaction intermediates [53]. The main drawbacks of such catalysts are related to the high prices of the metals used and a narrow operating window. With that, the Ag-containing catalysts are usually considered promising systems for NH3-SCR due to a combination of high activity and hydrothermal stability as well as relatively low costs. Such active component was supported on silica [11], titania [37], bauxite [168], CexZryOz [39], gallium oxide [126], and materials based on manganese oxides (e.g., MnO2 [161], OMS-2 [112]). Expectedly, the synergistic effects of silver with MnOx, CeO2 or TiO2 that were also shown in other catalytic reactions (e.g., [111,40,77]) were accounted for during the development of various SCR catalysts, including but not limited to MnO2-containing Ag/TiO2 [66], Ag-modified Mn-Ce/Al2O3 [15] or Ag-doped MnOx-CeO2/Ti-bearing blast furnace slag catalyst [100]. The research interest is mostly concentrated on alumina-supported systems due to high effectiveness in the presence of various hydrocarbons comparable with the one of commercial NH3-SCR catalysts at temperatures above 300 °C. Compared to Pt group metals, silver features lower activity in the total oxidation of HC/OHC resulting in a reduction of the loss of hydrocarbons or oxygenates through the competing reaction of total combustion during NOx SCR. Several main aspects were considered. The preparation procedures leading to the formation of high-performance catalyst bring about high attention and focus on the support preparation (e.g., modification with chloride [163], Ti and Si dopants [38]) and pretreatment procedures (e.g., effects derived from plasma treatment [121,122]). As a result, the shape-controlled synthesis [119] and the opportunities to control the structure–activity relationship [79,96] are in focus. Special attention is given to optimal Ag loading [18,19] and revealing the nature of active sites [110,35,8] and Ag states [145,178,179] in such catalysts. The reductant effects [71] were also considered with a special focus being given to the adsorption strength of reducing agents [32,33]. Various mixed-bed combinations of Ag/Al2O3 catalysts with other SCR composites (e.g., CuSn/ZSM-5 [85], Pd/Al2O3 [84], WO3/Cex-ZryO2 [5]) showed positive effects on the catalyst performance. Despite decreasing the SOx content in diesel engine exhausts, the S tolerance enhancement of the Ag-based HC-SCR catalysts remains a challenge. The reason for that is related to the SOx involvement in interactions with active sites (both of silver, alumina and other catalyst components) to yield surface sulfate species, which hinders NOx reduction [169]. While such species are considered stable, their mobility at the Ag–O–Al interface was also mentioned as a factor affecting the catalyst performance [182]. The SO2 removal was shown to allow regenerating the Ag/Al2O3 catalyst, while the regeneration ability also depended on the Ag loading in the catalyst as well as other factors (e.g., type of HC reductant, the use of H2 additives, regeneration temperature, the presence of alkali modifiers, etc.). It is noteworthy that competitive adsorption of SO2 and NO that was found in the case of other SCR catalyst formulations can occur [190,27,95]. Yet, the mechanisms of SOx involvement, the application of improved preparation procedures ensuring enhanced selectivity towards NO oxidation as well as the interplay of factors that govern the observed performance can be a subject matter of future research. The highest activities were achieved at Ag loading of 2–4% [127], however, the inadequate catalytic activity of Ag/Al2O3 catalysts at temperatures below 300 °C limits their practical application. To improve the features of such catalysts at low operating temperatures several approaches were proposed, e.g., the use of other components (e.g., based on Ce, Mn, etc.), enhanced preparation procedures as well as the use of alternative supports. For instance, the ethanol-SCR in the range of 150–400 °C was studied over silver catalysts supported on MgO, Y2O3, CuO, CeO2, SiO2, Al2O3 and MgO-CeO2-Al2O3 [157]. The MgO-, CeO2- and Al2O3-based catalysts showed higher yields of N2 and CO2 and the widest operating window. Mixed MgO-CeO2-Al2O3 support additionally allowed improving the properties of catalysts, including high stability in the presence of water and SO2. The catalyst 0.1%wt Ag/MgO-CeO2-Al2O3 showed 96% selectivity towards N2 at 40% NO conversion and 150–400 °C with O2 excess [128]. The addition of 1000 ppm ethanol into the gas mixture improved the selectivity and conversion up to 99% and 90%, respectively, at 250 °C. It is noteworthy that the potential of bi- and polymetallic SCR catalyst formulations is not yet unlocked. Bimetallic catalyst compositions are known to show improved catalyst performance as compared to the same catalysts based on individual metals. This finding is usually related to the synergistic effect of metals that was shown in a number of environmental catalytic reactions, including but not limited to Ag-Pd [10,154,41], Ag-Pt [70], and Ag-Cu [57,148] pairs. Bimetallic SCR catalysts were also proposed, and they are usually based on the most frequently studied SCR systems: - Mn (e.g., Mn-Co, Mn-Ni, and Mn-Cu [141], Me-Mn (Me=Cr, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, and Zn) [134]), - Cu (Me-Cu (Me = Cr, Mn, Co and Fe) [124], N-coordinated Cu-Fe [26,36], BTC-supported Cu-Al [140], zeolite-supported Cu-Ni [25]), - Fe (Fe-Ni [55], CNT-supported Fe-Mn [88]) and their combinations, - noble-metals: Pt (carbon-supported Pt-Ni [156], Pt-Cu [87]), Ru (alumina-supported Ir-Ru [3], zeolite-supported Ru-In [189]). Compared to individual metal-based systems, the bimetallic catalysts usually feature a wider operating window and enhanced low-temperature activity connected with the synergistic interaction between active components and promoters, strengthening the acid and redox properties. At the same time, some of these formulations utilize toxic elements (e.g., Cr) or imply demanding multistep synthetic procedures. With that, relatively poor information is available on Ag-based bimetallic SCR catalysts. Therefore, in the present review we have considered worth of investigating the recent findings in bimetallic Ag-containing SCR systems. Despite wide research interest towards SCR catalysts and a large number of review articles covering various SCR-related aspects, there is lack of systematized information on the bimetallic Ag-based SCR catalysts, while a growing research attention has recently been given to this topic. While a recent review article [80] considers the alumina-supported Ag catalysts for SCR NOx with C1-C4 oxygenates, it thoroughly covers only monometallic Ag-based systems and only oxygenates as reductants, and provides limited insights and discussion on the effects of second metals in the composition of Ag-based catalysts. Thus, the effects that exist in bimetallic catalyst formulations require close attention. 2 Bi- and polymetallic Ag-containing SCR systems Recently, bimetallic Ag-containing SCR catalysts have brought about research interest. Silver is known to form bimetallic composites with various metals, while only several of them have already been probed as components of SCR composites. Thus, the formation of Ag-Ni [207], Ag-Cu [131,175,194,67], Ag-Pt [133,149,46,48,63], Ag-Au [115-117], Ag-Fe [205], Ag-Pd-Ti [65], Ag-Pr [69] were reported. Table 1 lists the recent findings concerning the Ag-containing bimetallic catalysts. Other bimetallic SCR catalyst formulations are also included to provide opportunities for comparison. Generally, in such composites, silver plays either the role of the main active component or the dopant/promoter/modifier. The states and sizes of Ag species largely depend on the preparation method used (including the nature and effects of the second metal and other catalyst components). The materials engineering strategies utilizing silver as a component imply the use of high surface supports to disperse metallic species (ionic, cluster, NPs). Given the high synergy of silver with γ-Al2O3, the high-surface aluminas were used in composites mostly utilizing Pt [133,46,48] or Au [115-117] dopants. Such composites feature specific surface above 200 m2/g. The Ag loading in the composites showing higher NOx conversion was around 1–2%wt. Various approaches are used to synthesize Ag-containing bimetallic SCR catalysts. These include impregnation techniques (co-impregnation, successive impregnation, incipient wetness impregnation, etc.), sequential deposition as well as sol-gel, ion exchange, and preassembled methods (Table 1). All composites demonstrate rather high SCR activity in the temperature range of 200–350 °C, with high-surface CuAg2.25-SAPO-34 NH3-SCR catalyst [175] (prepared by ion-exchange + low-temperature steam treatment) showing the highest activity closely followed by Ag-Mn–Ce/γ-Al2O3 NH3-SCR catalyst (sol-gel method) [15] and Ag0.5-Cu-BTC CO-SCR catalyst (preassembly method) [131] samples. The application of additional treatment procedures (e.g., steam or hydrogen treatment) can enhance the performance of catalyst components and improve the total activity of the material. In terms of reductant type used (hydrocarbon (HC), oxygenate (OHC), NH3, CO), several catalysts demonstrate rather low T50 value, e.g., Ag-Pd-Ti/cordierite OHC-SCR (prepared by impregnation) [65], Ag-Fe/Al-PILC HC-SCR (ultrasonic impregnation) [205], the Ag-Mn–Ce/γ-Al2O3 [15] and CuAg2.25-SAPO-34 [175] NH3-SCR catalysts, while Ag0.5-Cu-BTC [131] CO-SCR catalyst shows higher T50 values despite developed surface area. Over model systems, the NOx conversions close to 100% can be obtained in the processes utilizing NH3, CO, and hydrocarbons. With that, of interest are the processes utilizing oxygenates (e.g., a mixture of ethanol with biodiesel) and liquefied petroleum gas as they demonstrate the SCR activity below 300 °C and set the testing conditions closer to the realistic ones. 2.1 HC-SCR The NOx SCR processes utilizing hydrocarbons are widely represented in the literature, with propane [205], n-octane [48,63], decane [115-117] as well as a mixture of hydrocarbons comprising iso-octane, m-xylene, 1-octene, n-octane [125] being considered for Ag-based bimetallic SCR catalysts. Au, Pt, Fe and Bi were taken as a second metal in the composition of bimetallic catalysts. Detailed studies of alumina-supported Ag-Au HC-SCR catalysts prepared by successive impregnation revealed several aspects crucial for such systems. The bimetallic Ag–Au/Al2O3 catalyst prepared over high-surface alumina showed high NO reduction to N2 compared to the Au-containing sample, while the activity was similar to that of Ag-containing specimen [115]. Catalyst prereduction in hydrogen at 250 °C ensured the highest performance of the bimetallic sample caused by the presence of highly dispersed metallic Au species and Agn + clusters. For prereduced Au2AgAl and 2AgAuAl samples (2%wt of Au or Ag, respectively), the particle sizes were distributed in the ranges of 1–40 and 1–30 nm, respectively, with the latter sample featuring higher dispersion ( Fig. 2) [116]. Subsequent catalyst aging increased the low-temperature activity as compared to monometallic counterparts. Large particles (>30 nm) were not observed over aged Au2AgAl sample, while small particles (<10 nm) were formed for the 2AgAuAl sample featuring particle agglomeration. The order of metal introduction (Ag or Au) onto supports pre-impregnated with other metals (Au or Ag) showed a significant effect on the catalytic properties of the composites after aging [115]. For aged Au2AgAl catalyst (2%wt Au-1%wt Ag/Al2O3), the N2 selectivity reached 100% at 275 °C, while it was ~80% below 200 °С. In both cases, the catalyst surfaces were enriched with silver, while electronic disturbances reflected the differences in metal-metal interactions in as-prepared and aged bimetallic composites. The Au-Ag/Al2O3 catalyst showed the highest activity but lower high-temperature deactivation resistance due to effects on the redispersion/agglomeration processes. For such systems, the importance of the preparation method was mentioned, where the samples prepared by sequential deposition showed superior performance to those prepared by co-precipitation of aqueous solutions of HAuCl4 and AgNO3 [117]. The metallic behavior of intermetallic Au-Ag particles was strengthened upon applying aging procedures. The nature and structure of active sites in such catalysts depending on the order of component introduction can be further explored with advanced experimental and theoretical techniques. More efforts are also required to reveal the exact factors affecting the strength of the intermetallic and metal-support interactions. For the Ag-Pt/Al2O3 HC-SCR catalyst prepared by sol-gel method and featuring trace amounts of Pt, the effect of Ag and Pt contents on the distribution of Ag species, activation of hydrocarbon (n-octane), and low-temperature activity was demonstrated [48]. Ultralow Pt content allowed enhancing the low-temperature activity that was caused by increased ability to activate the reductant due to the presence of Pt. Adsorption of higher amounts of hydrocarbons ensured higher fuel efficiency. The addition of trace amounts of Pt (100 ppm by weight) followed by hydrogen treatment was shown to increase the NOx conversion at high C/N ratios with n-octane used as a reductant [63]. Pt was assumed to act as an oxidative site that partially oxidized the reductant. With that, high compatibility and synergistic effects of Ag and Pt with ceria [47,135] can be further explored while developing the ceria-modified Ag-containing bimetallic SCR catalysts. Of interest is the activity potential of single-atom Pt and Ag sites that can be formed in such systems. Alumina-supported bimetallic Ag-Bi catalyst showed NOx conversion above 85% in the temperature range of 380–450 °C with a Bi content of 0.0075%wt. in the HC-SCR process [125]. The 95%wt. Ag in the catalyst was assumed to exist in a non-zero oxidation state. The calcined material was obtained at 540 °C for 2 h. With that, more information is required about the surface phase composition of such catalysts as well as the structure of bimetallic Ag-Bi active sites. Bimetallic Ag-Fe/Al-PILC (pillared interlayer clay) catalysts, with increasing Ag loading and fixed Fe content or vice versa, were prepared by ultrasonic impregnation, and the SCR-C3H6 activity was studied in a simulated flue gas atmosphere [205]. Compared to common alumina support, the PILC-based catalysts can feature enhanced water and SOx tolerance and lower the HC-SCR reaction temperature. In Fig. 3, the NO conversion curves for the two series of catalysts are shown. As reported in Fig. 3(a), the NO conversion over the Ag-Fe/Al-PILC catalysts was higher than that of the Fe/Al-PILC sample below 300 °C, then between 350 and 550 °C, the monometallic iron performed slightly better than the 2.1Ag-Fe/Al-PILC that was confirmed to have the best composition. Further increase in Ag loading with respect to Ag 2.1 had a negative effect on the SCR activity of the catalysts likely due to the blocking of the catalyst micro-channels of the Al-PILC by Ag agglomeration. Catalysts with fixed Ag loading and increasing Fe content were also prepared [205]. In details, the catalyst compositions were 2.1Ag/7Fe/Al-PILC, 2.1Ag/8Fe/Al-PILC, 2.1Ag/10Fe/Al-PILC, and 2.1Ag/12Fe/Al-PILC. As presented in Fig. 3(b), the NO conversions over all the catalysts reached more than 70% at 250 °C, with the 2.1Ag/8Fe/Al-PILC being the most active. The resistance against SO2 and H2O was also tested for the 2.1Ag/Fe/Al-PILC and Fe/Al-PILC catalysts. A transient decrease of the catalytic performance after exposure to SO2 and H2O was observed, however, after removal of the poisoning agents the NO conversion values were restored for both catalysts, with the Ag 2.1 always performing better than the monometallic Fe. The so far reported data were attributed to the formation of surface Ag-Fe solid solution and cationic Ag species. The synergistic effect of Ag and Fe caused by electronic transfer affected the valence states of metals and improved their performance. The Ag addition facilitated the low-temperature NO reduction capacity and enhanced the stability of Brønsted acid sites. The bimetallic Ag-based catalysts were also tested in H2-assisted HC-SCR processes. Thus, the Ag–Ti–Cu/cordierite catalyst was proposed for low-temperature SCR process with liquefied petroleum gas (LPG, ~72% C3H8) and hydrogen-liquefied petroleum gas (H2-LPG) mixture as reductants [67]. No bimetallic particles were found on the catalyst surface. The presence of H2 improved the low-temperature NOx conversion, while more information on the LPG composition is required to correctly assess the reductant effects. Recently, the 0.1 wt%Pt-2 wt%Ag/Al2O3-WOx catalyst was proposed [46]. The utilization of a combination of low- and high-temperature activities of Pt and Ag, respectively, was assumed. The composite surface contained ionic and cluster Ag species as well as Pt–Ag nanoparticles. The role of WOx was linked with the stabilization of alumina above 650 °C and Pt species at 800 °C towards ageing. In particular, it was observed that by increasing the W/Pt ratio, the Pt dispersion decreases and this effect was more pronounced in the samples reduced at 500 °C than for those reduced at 800 °C ( Fig. 4). A two-peak conversion was observed for 0.1 wt%Pt-2 wt%Ag/Al2O3-WOx composite [46] with the maxima of ~80% (at 130 °C) and 91% (between 260 and 350 °C), respectively ( Fig. 5). The presence of Pt increased the C3H8 chemisorption to result in its higher conversion over bimetallic species in comparison with the 2Ag/AW catalyst. The reasons for two-peak conversion behavior were assumed to be associated with the effects of preadsorbed oxygen species or the simultaneous use of several reductants (C3H8, CO, and H2). The enhancement of low-temperature NOx reduction was linked with the C3H8 chemisorption increase favored by the formation of small amounts of Pt on the Ag particles as well as NO-to-NO2 oxidation with the participation of surface oxygen species. Nevertheless, additional studies are required to reveal the exact surface composition in terms of distributed mono- and bimetallic active sites as well as to distinguish the roles of each reductant in the mixture. The low- and high-temperature intrinsic activities of Pt and Ag species, respectively, can also be considered. 2.2 OHC-SCR In many cases, oxygenates showed improved reducing ability and lower light-off temperatures as compared to conventional hydrocarbons [80]. Recently, OHC reductants representing 100% 2-propanol, 95% 2-propanol-5% AdBlue, 90% 2-propanol-10% AdBlue [65], 2-propanol-toluene [194], and biodiesel (15%) + ethanol (85%) [133] have been considered, while Pt, Pd, Cu and Mn additives have been used in OHC-SCR processes. Thus, the Ag-Pt pair on Al2O3-containing supports has recently attracted wide research interest. Such catalysts showed rather high SCR performance when a mixture of 15% biodiesel and 85% ethanol was used as a reductant [133]. The tests were carried out varying the engine loads and exhaust gas temperatures. With that, rather high Ag content was applied that resulted in particular hindering of Ag distribution in the form of nanoparticles/clusters on the cordierite surface that usually feature rather low specific surface. The effects of additional modifiers (e.g., ceria) can be further studied. The Ag-Pd-Ti/cordierite catalyst prepared by impregnation approach was used in the HC-SCR process utilizing 2-propanol and different mixtures of 2-propanol and adBlue (aqueous solution of highly purified urea) as reductants [65]. The presence of 2-propanol had a positive effect on the NOx conversion. When the HC and CO concentrations increased, an additional reductant effect leading to improved NOx conversion was observed. With that, the competition of reductants should be further clarified. The Ag-Cu-Pt-Ce/cordierite monolithic catalyst was also prepared [194] and showed moderate NOx conversion at 260 °C in the SCR process with the 2-propanol-toluene mixture as a reductant. The authors assumed high dispersion of metals on the surface and in pores of the support. With that, the exact distribution of metals on the surface, the formation of bimetallic species, their morphology, the effect of ceria on the probable formation of single-atom species remained unclear. It was not clear also how the cordierite composition affected the processes of formation of Ag-M bimetallic species and their segregation. Moreover, cordierite features a geometric surface that results in hindered distribution of small particles. The bimetallic Ag-containing formulations supported on titania-based supports have also brought about a research interest. Thus, the Ag-Mn/TiO2 catalyst for the low-temperature ethanol-SCR process was synthesized by the wash coating method [66]. Both Ag and MnOx species were assumed to feature strong interaction with the support. The effectiveness of low-temperature NO removal strongly depended on the MnOx content, and the role of Mn was assumed to be related to providing active areas on the catalyst surface. 2.3 NH3-SCR The interest towards NH3 as a reducing agent originates from its large application in commercial stationary combustion units and its involvement in several SCR reactions including “fast SCR” (4NH3 +2NO+2NO2→4 N2 +6 H2O) [51]. Recently, the granular Ag-doped Mn–Ce/γ-Al2O3 catalysts for low-temperature NH3-SCR have shown high performance both in low- and middle-temperature ranges and demonstrated high activity and GHSV tolerance [15]. The catalytic activity performances of two Ag catalysts were compared with the metal-free MnCe as a function of temperature as shown in Fig. 6(a). It resulted that the catalytic activity of 2AgMnCe was generally higher by 5–10% in the entire temperature window in comparison with MnCe catalyst, moreover, the Ag catalyst performed better than the support only at low temperature (100–300 °C). The 2AgMnCe catalyst achieved up to 85% NO conversion at 200 °C and reached 95% at 250–300 °C. By further increasing the Ag loading to 4 wt%, the SCR activity slightly increased at high temperatures (350–450 °C), while the effect was negligible in the range of 100–300 °C. The GHSV tolerance for 2AgMnCe catalyst is displayed in Fig. 6(b). Only slight differences were observed when the GHSV increased from 10,000 h−1 to 15,000 h−1, while an obvious decrease occurred for GHSV equal to 30,000 h−1, although NO conversion values nearly 85% at 250 °C were achieved indicating that the 2AgMnCe catalyst is effective for NO removal in a wide range of GHSV. The performance of Ag–Mn–Ce/γ-Al2O3 was most likely achieved due to the even distribution of metal species prepared by addition of metal nitrates into boehmite sols. The co-existence of Ag and Ag2O species facilitated the migration of active surface oxygen species and increased the number of weak Brønsted and strong Lewis acid sites. The Ag addition was favorable for NO adsorption to yield mainly bridged nitrite and bidentate nitrate species. The O2 addition facilitated the NO oxidation to yield unstable monodentate nitrate, bridged nitrite, and nitrate species as well as coordinated NH3 and NH2 species. The Ag–Mn–Ce ensemble was also organized on the Ti-containing support. Thus, the Ti-bearing blast furnace slag was used as a support for Mn–Ce–M (M = Fe, Co, Ag) systems and was prepared by the solution impregnation method [100]. The Ag addition was shown to reduce the SCR activity as opposed to Co or Fe dopants. This was assumed to be caused by the high strength of acid sites over the Ag-containing surface preventing the NH3 desorption. The Pt/Ag/Al2O3 sample prepared by wetness impregnation [149] surprisingly showed lower NH3-SCR activity than the Pt-less counterpart that could be due to the hydrogen oxidation on Pt accompanied by silver oxidation resulting in the reduced dynamic number of Ag-related NOx storage sites as well as the absence of direct Ag-Pt interactions. Promotion of high-surface Cu-SAPO-34 composite with Ag showed improved low-temperature hydrothermal stability [175]. The Ag addition regulated the strength of Lewis acid sites to demonstrate a positive effect against low-temperature steam treatment, improved NH3 adsorption on such weak/moderate sites, and preserving the total acid sites. The hydrolysis of acid Si-OH-Al sites was also partially inhibited ( Fig. 7). 2.4 CO-SCR The CO-SCR brings about research interest since CO exists in the exhaust gases implying no need in an additional reducing agent. Moreover, in the presence of appropriate catalysts, both NOx and CO can be simultaneously converted into N2 and CO2 [206]. Recent research activity was focused on the exploring the opportunities to utilize Ag-based bimetallic species within the MOF structures. Thus, Ag-Ni-MOF-74 [207] and Ag-Cu-BTC [131] were proposed that featured specific surface areas as high as 876 and 1243 m2/g, respectively. The hydrothermal synthesis followed by the post-synthesis approach was used to prepare low-temperature Agx-Ni1−x-MOF-74 CO-SCR catalysts [207]. The SCR activity of this composite exceeded the one of the Ag-less sample. The effect of Ag additive was connected with surface enrichment with active sites and improved surface area that resulted in better activation and transfer of the reactants. The enhanced activity was attributed to the synergism of silver and nickel species expressed through the formation of oxygen vacancies and improved electron transfer in surface reactions. It seems that the potential of various MOFs, e.g., CeO2-based materials [144], can be further applied to synthesize new Ag-containing composites. The effects of cooperation of oxygen vacancies and surface active sites containing bimetallic species in activation and transformation of reaction components can be further studied. The preassembled method utilizing trimesic acid and Cu nitrate was used to prepare a high-surface Agx-Cu-BTC catalyst with a regular octahedral shape ( Fig. 8) [131]. The Ag effect was associated with the facilitation of the catalyst activity and increasing the number of active sites. Small amounts of oxide impurities (Cu2O, CuO, Ag2O) resulted from the reduction of Cu and Ag nitrates by ethanol were found. With that, the potential of recently developed Ag-based MOFs, e.g., Ag-BDC (BDC = 1,4-benzene dicarboxylate) as well as those used in other branches of industry (e.g., Ag3(3-phosphonobenzoate) [9]), can be further explored. Moreover, the silver precursors, e.g., silver–ammonia or silver–ethylenediamine complex [62], as well as di- and tetranuclear complexes with other metals (e.g., Ag-Pt [78]) can be further used in the preparation of new generations of catalysts. 3 Current understanding of structure-performance relationships Basically, two types of Ag-containing SCR catalysts are considered in the literature: (1) Ag is an active component, while other metals (Pt, Au, etc.) are added to further strengthen the Ag performance, (2) Ag is a dopant that affects the performance of other metals (e.g., Cu, Fe, etc.). Among the composites reported recently those featuring small Ag loadings evenly distributed over high-surface area supports (i.e., MOFs or high-surface alumina) usually demonstrate higher SCR performance in terms of activity and hydrothermal stability (Table 1). In such cases Ag controls the strength of the surface Lewis acid sites. It is noteworthy that the impact of the intrinsic SCR activity normalized per surface area can be further understood. With that, alumina-supported composites having transition metal oxide modifiers in their composition (e.g., a combination of Ce and Mn) can show comparable performance caused by the organization on the support surface of active sites of different nature (i.e., Ag, AgxOy, CeOx, MnOx species; oxygen vacancies and other support and/or modifier defects). The composite performance is determined by the interplay of such sites, their mutual location and distribution on the catalyst surface and the derived interfaces (e.g., metal-metal, metal-oxide, oxide-oxide). For such composites, one can expect enhanced SCR performance caused by improved redox ability depending on the amount of oxygen vacancies. The balance between redox properties and acidity becomes a crucial aspect, and its effect on the adsorption, activation and transformation of reaction components can be further elucidated. In bimetallic catalysts having d element (Au, Pt, etc.) as a second metal high performance can be achieved when the second component exists on the catalyst surface in a highly dispersed state, while silver forms charged cluster states balanced by ionic and metallic ones. The second metal can tune the surface acidity and alter the adsorptive properties of silver [115]. With that, the nanostructure of the alloyed bimetallic particles that can also be formed especially upon sample reduction or when the coprecipitation is used remains poorly described. The sequential impregnation (e.g., by Au and Ag compounds) shows superior activity as compared to coprecipitation emphasizing the crucial role of the preparation method. Yet few information is available on the effects of different parameters of metal-support interactions (e.g., interfacial perimeter and morphology effects of metal species on the surface, charge transfer options, etc.) that can appear upon variation of the preparation method. Thus, the current understanding of the structure-performance relationship and opportunities to control it are at their start and the potential of synergistic effects of catalyst components can be further unlocked to organize the active surface sites with predesigned structure and performance. 4 Current understanding of the nature of Ag active species and the role of a second metal Ag/Al2O3 catalysts with different silver loadings (from 0.5 to 4 wt%) were studied by photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), X-ray absorption near-edge spectroscopy (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure spectroscopy (EXAFS) combined with theoretical calculation (DFT) in order to clarify the role of active species in NO SCR by ethanol [35]. In Fig. 9(a), the NOx conversions over Ag/Al2O3 catalysts with different silver loadings and in absence of any catalyst are shown. The optimum silver content for the NO SCR was in the range between 1%wt. and 2%wt., and for such loadings silver species in the oxidation state close to Ag+ were the active sites for NOx reduction. As demonstrated by DFT, the most active silver ion seems to be anchored on a tricoordinate Al III site (Ag−O−Al III) and the hybridization of Ag, O, and Al orbitals promoted its catalytic activity. At low silver loadings, also the N2 selectivity was enhanced, with the 1%wt. Ag exhibiting the highest N2 selectivity, ~76% in a 100 °C temperature window (382 −486 °C). When silver loading increased to 2%wt., the EXAFS analysis revealed the presence of metallic Ag that was beneficial only for low-temperature activity. Further increasing the Ag content to 4%wt. significantly decreased in the whole temperature range the NOx conversion and the selectivity to N2, with the promotion of the NH3 selectivity to 40%, and NH3 being a common byproduct of NO SCR by ethanol (Fig. 9b). As far as we know, for most of the bimetallic Ag-M pairs, no detailed studies of the effects of the modifier or second metal have been carried out yet. For Ag-Pt pair, the coexistence of ionic, cluster and metal Ag species was found, and the Ag oxidation states as well as their ratio remained almost intact depending on the Ag loading and/or Pt doping [48]. The electronic effects of the second metal resulted in different behavior: while the sample doped with Pt showed improved low-temperature activity, the one doped with Au showed only slight changes. The Pt addition also alters the ability to oxidize hydrocarbon over Ag/Al2O3 catalysts resulting in two conversion modes that are due to the increased hydrocarbon adsorption on the surface. The presence of Pt also favors the NOx activation with enhanced reduction at low temperature. However, due to the high activity of platinum group metal in the oxidation of hydrocarbons and oxygenates leading to oxidation reaction, small additives of Pt (<0.5%wt.) allowed improving the catalyst features in the multicomponent catalytic systems at low temperatures, maintaining high NO SCR selectivity and without any effect on the side reactions at elevated temperatures. The modifying metal can show different effects depending on the introduction method used. This is caused by different types of surface interactions occurring when different order of introduction of Ag and the second metal is used and different surface sites are involved. It is noteworthy that for Ag-Au pair, depending on the preparation method used, a superior performance can be achieved in terms of NOx conversion rate, while the high-temperature deactivation resistance can be lower due to redispersion/agglomeration processes [115]. The use of modifiers based on transition metal oxides allows improving the distribution of target species of both Ag and the second metal and preventing their agglomeration at elevated temperatures. Moreover, such modifiers also affect the performance of the second component through the formation of joint interfaces, while little is known about their composition and structure. 5 Mechanisms of SCR NOx over mono and bimetallic Ag-based catalysts Over monometallic Ag/Al2O3 catalysts, different mechanisms were reported in the literature depending on the experimental conditions used. The addition of H2 has been reported to promote significantly the selective catalytic reduction of NOx by hydrocarbons (HC SCR). However, the influence of the Ag loading on the H2-promoted HC SCR has been the subject of a very limited number of investigations. Studies on H2-HC-SCR reported mostly on Ag/Al2O3 samples containing about 2%wt. Ag, since this particular loading has been shown to provide optimum catalytic performances in the HC-SCR reaction in the absence of H2 [18]. The authors concluded that an Ag loading equal to 2.2%wt. corresponding to an Ag surface density close to 0.7Ag/nm2 Al2O3, corresponds to the maximum Ag surface density for which Ag2O clusters remain highly dispersed. Some years later, the same authors, highlighted for the first time, in the [19], that the H2-C3H6-SCR catalytic performances of Ag/Al2O3 samples were improved in the range 150–550 °C as the Ag loading decreased below 2%wt. The unexpected higher catalytic performances of the Ag samples with the lower Ag surface densities were attributed to the higher concentration of active sites on the Al2O3 supporting oxide able to chemisorb NOx species, in agreement with the NOx uptake data (see Fig. 10). According to the activity and kinetic data in the H2-C3H6-SCR reaction, H2 and C3H6 are activated on Ag species to react with adsorbed NOx species that are activated on the alumina, as schematized in Fig. 11. At Ag loadings higher than 2.2%wt., namely for Ag surface densities higher than 0.7Ag/nm2 Al2O3 larger Ag particles are formed that promote the C3H6 combustion. Based on the kinetic data recorded for catalysts with Ag surface densities lower than 0.7Ag/nm2 Al2O3 it was concluded that the C3H6–NOx interaction is the rate-determining step in the SCR process. The role of silver species in H2-NH3-SCR of NOx over Ag/Al2O3 catalysts was highlighted by operando spectroscopy (DRIFTS-MS and DR-UV–Vis) and DFT calculations [179]. It was demonstrated that metallic silver clusters contributed to the formation of nitrates which further react with NH3 adsorbed on Brønsted acid sites to generate N2. Subsequently, the Brønsted acid sites were restored by H2 that was dissociated on metallic silver clusters. A comprehensive quantum-chemical study of the structure and properties of an Ag/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, with a silver fraction more than 2%wt., has been carried out by DFT calculations and cluster models [110]. Five different cluster models were proposed to simulate the (110) γ-Al2O3 surface ( Fig. 12). The most reliable results were obtained within embedded cluster models with “soft” charges (models 4 and 5). The nature of silver-containing catalytic sites was also studied, and the existence of neutral and positively charged small silver clusters on the γ-Al2O3 surface was demonstrated on the basis of the calculated adsorption and dissociation energies. The adsorbed silver clusters Ag2 −Ag4 were found to be stable towards dissociation on the γ-Al2O3 surface. The calculations indicated that the NO (and N2O2) adsorption on the supported Ag clusters was more favorable as compared to N2O. A reaction mechanism to explain the experimental data was proposed ( Fig. 13) assuming that acetaldehyde was formed during the SCR process from ethylene or ethanol in the gas phase [110]. Considering that H2O is inevitably present in diesel engine exhausts, the design of catalysts with excellent water resistance is highly desired for practical application. In Ref. [178], the influence of the Ag valence state on the H2O tolerance of 2%wt. Ag/alumina catalysts for H2 −C3H6 −SCR of NOx was investigated. Characterizations by XPS, UV−vis, and XANES were performed on the catalysts calcined at temperatures from 500° to 900°C. It resulted that oxidized Ag species were predominant on samples calcined below 600 °C (LT catalysts), while increasing the calcination temperature above 600 °C (HT-catalysts) promoted the formation of metallic silver clusters. Samples containing Ag+ cations exhibited better water tolerance in the H2 −C3H6 −SCR. Activation energy measurements were performed over the Ag/Al2O3 catalysts calcined at different temperatures in order to understand the mechanism of H2 −C3H6 −SCR. The Arrhenius plots are shown in Fig. 14 and the calculated apparent activation energies (Ea) for NOx conversion are listed in Table 2. It results that the Ea values varied from 71.5 to 81.3 kJ/mol in agreement with the literature. As shown in Table 2, for the Ag/Al2O3 catalysts calcined at different temperatures, similar Ea values for NOx conversion were found. This result indicated that the same reaction pathway occurred at low temperatures over all samples. In Scheme 1, the proposed NOx reaction mechanism is displayed. The main pathway for NOx reduction at low temperatures is as follows: NO + C3H6 + H2 + O2 → ad-NOx + enolic species → R−ONO + R-NO2 → −NCO + −CN → N2. When the reaction was carried out in the presence of water, the elimination of the formate occurred releasing the active Ag+ sites for enolic species formation, and, thus, the low-temperature activity of LT catalysts was promoted. To sum up, the higher the percentage of oxidized silver species, the higher the water tolerance in NOx reduction is, indicating that the amount of oxidized silver species determines the water tolerance of Ag/Al2O3 for NOx reduction. 60% of oxidized silver species is the optimal percentage for deNOx performance and water tolerance in the H2 −C3H6 −SCR over the investigated Ag/Al2O3 catalysts. To the best of our knowledge, yet there were few specific studies concerning the detailed mechanism of SCR NOx over bimetallic Ag-containing catalysts. For Ag-Au pair, the NO-to-NO2 oxidation over metallic species was claimed to be the rate-limiting step [115]. Moreover, it was demonstrated that the Ag+/Ag0 ratio determines the activity, and the equilibration of oxidation states of gold and silver species is a key parameter where the metallic species are required for oxidizing NO to NO2, and isolated silver species are useful for catalyzing the HC SCR. The beneficial effect of gold on monometallic Ag catalysts was confirmed, and interestingly the HC SCR activity depended on the order of introduction of the two metals. For Ag–Ti–Cu/cordierite catalyst involved in SCR reaction with NOx (NO/NO2 =1/1), LPG and H2 the general reaction C4H10 +NO+NO2 +H2 + 5.5 O2 =N2 + 4CO2 + 6 H2O was provided [67]. With that, future research can decipher the particular roles of each metal and the interfaces they form in the key reaction stages. While detailed studies of NH3-SCR mechanism over CuAg2.25-SAPO-34 catalyst can be a subject of future research [175], the Ag addition was assumed not to change the reaction mechanism, and Ag and Cu species feature small interactions with each other. The in-situ DRIFTS studies over Ag–Mn–Ce/γ-Al2O3 NH3-SCR catalyst revealed that the NO adsorption in the form of nitrite or nitrate species [15]. The Ag species facilitated the migration and activity of surface oxygen species. The adsorbed NH3 addition can react with adsorbed bridged nitrite and monodentate nitrate species. The latter can also be formed during the NO adsorption. The Langmuir-Hinshelwood reaction mechanism was assumed. With that, the role of oxygen vacancies in the process can be further clarified. More efforts were given to MOF-based CO-SCR systems. Thus, for Ag0.5-Cu-BTC the formation of active Cu+ species upon Cu2+ reduction with CO was assumed ( Fig. 15) [131]. The Cu+(CO)n (n = 1–3) and Cu+(NO)m (m=1–2) species were formed during the adsorption of CO and NO, respectively. Competitive CO adsorption was assumed to occur over Ag+ sites yielding Ag+(CO)n (n = 1–2) or Ag+ nCO (n = 2–4). The Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism was assumed. For Ag1-Ni-MOF-74 [207] the authors assumed the CO-SCR reaction to proceed via the following mechanism: (1) MO＋CO(g)→CO(ads) (2) MO＋NO(g)→NO(ads) (3) MO＋CO(ads)→CO2(g)＋M–[] (4) M–[]＋NO(ads)→[N]＋[O] (5) CO(ads)＋[O]→CO2(g) (6) [N]＋[N]→N2(g) (7) [N]＋NO(ads)→N2O(ads) (8) N2O(ads)→N2(g)＋[O] This mechanism was assumed to be favored by the high surface area of bimetallic MOF-based catalysts that ensured easy adsorption of NO and CO molecules. The latter was assumed to bind to unsaturated metal sites. The NO activation occurred due to preliminary generation of oxygen vacancies. The [N] species recombination or interaction with adsorbed NO resulted in formation of molecular nitrogen or adsorbed N2O, with the latter species decomposing to N2 and [O]. 6 Conclusions and outlook The present review clearly shows the importance and high interest in the research and industrial fields towards various SCR catalysts. Indeed, the impact of catalysis-based solutions cannot be overestimated, and several cost-effective formulations utilizing Mn-, Cu-, Fe-, V-, W- based systems have been proposed in the latest 5–10 years. Generally, bi- and polymetallic catalyst formulations demonstrated enhanced performance as compared to counterparts based on individual metals. In particular, the review demonstrates that the Ag-containing bimetallic SCR catalysts can be competitive to bimetallic counterparts based on other noble metals. Being the topic of growing interest, such composites can be thoroughly studied using the up-to-date experimental and theoretical approaches applied to other catalysts. Further research can cover the following main aspects: 1. New synthesis and surface engineering strategies should be developed to ensure improved low-temperature SCR activity and resistances to SOx, moisture, alkali, and heavy metal poisons. While preparing the SCR catalysts, new metal precursors, e.g., the organometallic Ag complexes with Au, Pt, and other metals, can be considered. The Ag-containing MOFs can be used to develop high-surface composites. The additional application of promoters and modifiers in the composition can impose additional effects connected with the high synergism of noble metal and transition metal oxide leading to improved chemical resistance to poisons and mechanical stability, high fuel efficiency, and enhanced activity of the SCR catalysts. Additional effects can be induced by applying various treatment procedures (e.g., plasma, prereduction). Mixed-bed combinations of bimetallic Ag-containing SCR catalysts with other catalyst compositions can yield synergistic effects and further enhance the activity. 2. The nature and structure of active sites in the Ag-containing bimetallic catalysts can be further clarified due to the coexistence of active sites of different nature (e.g., single-atom and ionic species, clusters as well as nanoparticles composed of several metals). The structure-performance relationships, as well as metal-support and/or metal-metal interactions, can be further studied. The inter- and intraparticle interactions of defective sites and the approaches to control their distribution and strength are of particular importance. Besides, such factors as the morphology of bimetallic particles, their segregation mechanism, the effect of the second metal on the oxidation state of silver (and vice versa), solid proofs for the formation of bimetallic species are of profound importance and should be studied in detail. 3. More efforts should be directed at revealing the low-temperature SCR mechanisms over the Ag-containing bimetallic catalysts, with close attention being given to individual roles of catalyst components. The mechanism of the catalyst deactivation with the participation of bimetallic Ag–M particles and phases related to the second metal should be thoroughly studied. While developing new generations of SCR catalysts, it is crucial to account for the testing mixtures with realistic composition, i.e., in the presence of SO2 and/or water. coredata.dc:description: The abatement of nitrogen oxides coming to the atmosphere from diesel engines of automotive vehicles and marine vessels, industrial plants, and other sources is of profound importance. Currently, catalysis-based solutions show growing potential in addressing this challenge. The main requirements that SCR catalysts should meet include enhanced low-temperature activity and selectivity combined with a broad operating window, high resistance to poisons and moisture. While a plethora of SCR catalysts has been proposed by now, recently, a growing number of publications have emphasized the unlocked potential of bimetallic catalyst formulations. Among them, Ag-based systems deserve special attention due to their high performance and relative cheapness. The present review is focused on the recent achievements recorded in the latest 5–10 years on bimetallic Ag-based catalysts for low-temperature SCR. Systems, such as Ag-Pt, Ag-Au, Ag-Cu, Ag-Fe, Ag-Mn, are considered and compared with bi-and polymetallic transition metals. The role of catalysts preparation method, Ag loading, metal-support interaction and pre-treatment effects has been pointed out. The outlook of the future research challenges is provided.
coredata.dc:title: Bimetallic Ag-based catalysts for low-temperature SCR: Quo vadis?
